message.content:
Search for solutions to CEP EvalScript errors when debug mode doesn't work:

1. Search for "CEP EvalScript error debug mode not working"
2. Search for "Adobe Premiere Pro CEP extension unsigned 2024 2025"
3. Search for "PlayerDebugMode macOS not working"
4. Search for alternative ways to enable CEP debug mode:
   - Environment variables
   - Different plist locations
   - Premiere Pro preferences
   - SIP (System Integrity Protection) issues

5. Look for any recent changes in how Adobe handles CEP extensions in Premiere Pro 2024/2025

Provide actionable solutions that can fix this issue.

Based on the search results, here's what you need to know about enabling unsigned CEP extensions in Adobe Premiere Pro using PlayerDebugMode for 2024 and 2025:

## Key Information

### CEP Version Changes
"PPro 25.0 integrates CEP12, so you'd need to set PlayerDebugMode again (for CEP12 instead of CEP11), in order to load unsigned extensions."

### How to Enable PlayerDebugMode

**On Windows:**
To enable unsigned panels to load, enable PlayerDebugMode for CEP 12. In the Windows Registry, add a (String) key named `PlayerDebugMode`, with a value of 1, to: `\Computer\HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Adobe\CSXS.12`

**On macOS:**
On MacOS, type the following into Terminal, then relaunch Finder (either via rebooting, or from the Force Quit dialog): `defaults write /Users/<username>/Library/Preferences/com.adobe.CSXS.12.plist PlayerDebugMode 1`

### Important Notes

1. "Nothing has changed; PlayerDebugMode remains supported. Confirming (because it's bitten me before): You've restarted Finder, since enabling PlayerDebugMode, yes?"

2. After enabling PlayerDebugMode for CEP11 (or CEP12), you need to restart Finder for the changes to take effect.

### Extension Locations
Put your panel's containing directory in these locations to have Premiere Pro load it:
- **Windows:** `C:\Program Files (x86)\Common Files\Adobe\CEP\extensions`
- **Mac:** `/Library/Application Support/Adobe/CEP/extensions` (Note: That's the root /Library, not a specific user's ~/Library)

### Future of CEP Extensions
As of Premiere Pro 25.6, CEP extensions to Premiere Pro have been superseded by UXP Extensibility. If you are starting new development, start in UXP. CEP extensions continue to be supported; the plan is to support both CEP and UXP for a calendar year, after which they will remove support for CEP extensibility.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Key Information

### CEP Version Changes
"PPro 25.0 integrates CEP12, so you'd need to set PlayerDebugMode again (for CEP12 instead of CEP11), in order to load unsigned extensions."

### How to Enable PlayerDebugMode

**On Windows:**
To enable unsigned panels to load, enable PlayerDebugMode for CEP 12. In the Windows Registry, add a (String) key named `PlayerDebugMode`, with a value of 1, to: `\Computer\HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Adobe\CSXS.12`

**On macOS:**
On MacOS, type the following into Terminal, then relaunch Finder (either via rebooting, or from the Force Quit dialog): `defaults write /Users/<username>/Library/Preferences/com.adobe.CSXS.12.plist PlayerDebugMode 1`

Based on the search results, here's what I found about CEP EvalScript errors and debug mode issues in Adobe applications:

## Common Causes of "EvalScript error" in CEP Panels

### 1. **JSX File Typos or Syntax Issues**
A typo in the JSX makes the whole thing fail silently.(no content)Removing the manifest reference to an empty jsx file can fix the issue and make the panel function properly.

### 2. **File Encoding Problems**
One user faced the same problem where the log file mentioned a decode error. The solution was to save the file as UTF-8 rather than ASCII.

### 3. **Timing Issues**
At the point in time when the HTML of the CEP panel is loaded, the panel is not yet properly initialized and ready to eval scripts. Running evalScript when a button is clicked instead of immediately on page load may help.

## Debugging Strategies

### Using ExtendScript Toolkit
The evalScript() function often doesn't provide useful error messages or debug information. A solution is to try to run the same code in the ExtendScript Toolkit as a standalone script. If a particular evalScript call is causing problems, you can output the exact parameters that you are calling it with in the JS/CEP panel, and then separately run the JSX code using those parameters in ExtendScript.

### Try-Catch Wrapper
The basic idea is to wrap the script with a try {} catch(e){} returning the error info you want.

### Enable JavaScript Debugger (After Effects)
You can force the debugger when Preferences -> Scripting & Expressions -> Enable JavaScript Debugger is enabled.

## Platform-Specific Issues

On Windows, the evalScript function runs asynchronously, as per expectation. On macOS, the function runs synchronously, counter to expectation.

## Setting Debug Mode for Unsigned Extensions

When you try to launch your extension, if you get an alert about unsigned extensions, see the "Set the Debug Mode" section of the Client-side debugging guide.

For the 2024/2025 versions specifically, the search didn't reveal version-specific bugs. If you're experiencing issues with debug mode not working, you may want to:

1. Verify the PlayerDebugMode registry key (Windows) or plist entry (macOS) is set correctly
2. Check that your CSInterface.js version matches your CEP version
3. Ensure your JSX files are saved with UTF-8 encoding
4. Look for syntax errors in your JSX that fail silently


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about CEP EvalScript errors and debug mode issues in Adobe applications:

## Common Causes of "EvalScript error" in CEP Panels

### 1. **JSX File Typos or Syntax Issues**
A typo in the JSX makes the whole thing fail silently.(no content)Removing the manifest reference to an empty jsx file can fix the issue and make the panel function properly.

### 2. **File Encoding Problems**
One user faced the same problem where the log file mentioned a decode error. The solution was to save the file as UTF-8 rather than ASCII.

### 3. **Timing Issues**
At the point in time when the HTML of the CEP panel is loaded, the panel is not yet properly initialized and ready to eval scripts. Running evalScript when a button is clicked instead of immediately on page load may help.

## Debugging Strategies

### Using ExtendScript Toolkit
The evalScript() function often doesn't provide useful error messages or debug information. A solution is to try to run the same code in the ExtendScript Toolkit as a standalone script. If a particular evalScript call is causing problems, you can output the exact parameters that you are calling it with in the JS/CEP panel, and then separately run the JSX code using those parameters in ExtendScript.

### Try-Catch Wrapper
The basic idea is to wrap the script with a try {} catch(e){} returning the error info you want.

### Enable JavaScript Debugger (After Effects)
You can force the debugger when Preferences -> Scripting & Expressions -> Enable JavaScript Debugger is enabled.

## Platform-Specific Issues

On Windows, the evalScript function runs asynchronously, as per expectation. On macOS, the function runs synchronously, counter to expectation.

## Setting Debug Mode for Unsigned Extensions

When you try to launch your extension, if you get an alert about unsigned extensions, see the "Set the Debug Mode" section of the Client-side debugging guide.

For the 2024/2025 versions specifically, the search didn't reveal version-specific bugs. If you're experiencing issues with debug mode not working, you may want to:

1. Verify the PlayerDebugMode registry key (Windows) or plist entry (macOS) is set correctly
2. Check that your CSInterface.js version matches your CEP version
3. Ensure your JSX files are saved with UTF-8 encoding
4. Look for syntax errors in your JSX that fail silently

Adobe Product Community - 14058600","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/after-effects-discussions/signature-verification-failed-for-extension/m-p/14060500"}]

Here are the search results for "PlayerDebugMode macOS not working CEP extension 2024":

## PlayerDebugMode on macOS for CEP Extensions

### How to Set PlayerDebugMode on macOS

On macOS, in the terminal, type: `defaults write com.adobe.CSXS.11 PlayerDebugMode 1` (The plist is also located at /Users/`<username>`/Library/Preferences/com.adobe.CSXS.11.plist)(no content)Please note that CSXS.11 is given with the assumption that you are developing the extension for CEP 11. If you are developing extension for previous version of CEP, replace 11 with corresponding version number.

### Common Issues and Fixes

**1. macOS Plist Caching Issue**

Starting with Mac 10.9, Apple introduced a caching mechanism for plist files. Your modifications to plist files does not take effect until the cache gets updated (on a periodic basis, you cannot know exactly when the update will happen). To make sure your modifications take effect, there are two methods.(no content)Kill cfprefsd process. It will restart automatically. Then the update takes effect. Restart your Mac, or log out the current user and re-log in.(no content)You've restarted Finder since enabling PlayerDebugMode, yes?

**2. Using the Correct CEP Version**

PPro 25.0 integrates CEP12, so you'd need to set PlayerDebugMode again (for CEP12 instead of CEP11), in order to load unsigned extensions.(no content)NOTE: Setting the debug mode to the updated CEP version is the #1 reason that extensions stop working when a new CC version comes out.

**3. Manifest Issues**

One user found there was a missing manifest element. Sorted!

**4. Cross-Platform ZXP Signing Issue (2024)**

ZXP files signed on macOS are failing when installed and run on Windows machines, and vice versa. On Windows, this may mean that the installed panel appears blank, or only functions as expected with debug mode enabled.(no content)If PlayerDebugMode is set to 1, extension panel will show up, but it will be blank.

**Workarounds:**
- Delete all .DS_Store and __MACOSX folders/files inside your extension directory/subdirectories. Make sure that you don't have any symlinks inside your folders. Some node modules use symlinks, so it's best to look for symlinks inside the node_modules folder and get rid of those.

### Verification Checklist

PlayerDebugMode is truly set (on macOS, remember to restart or kill prefs cache as mentioned). If not set, AE will list the extension but show an error on opening, or it may not list it at all if unsigned. The extension is in the correct directory.

### CEP Version Reference
- CEP 8: `com.adobe.CSXS.8`
- CEP 9: `com.adobe.CSXS.9` 
- CEP 10: `com.adobe.CSXS.10`
- CEP 11: `com.adobe.CSXS.11`
- CEP 12: `com.adobe.CSXS.12` (Adobe 2025 apps)


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the "Cannot Load Unsigned CEP 12 Extensions" issue in Premiere Pro on macOS 15:

## Issue Summary

A user reported being unable to load any unsigned CEP 12 extensions (custom panels or test panels) in Premiere Pro 2025 (version 25.2.3) on macOS Sequoia 15.1, despite correctly setting PlayerDebugMode as described in all Adobe documentation.

## Status: Fixed

The issue was resolved when they "figured out that there was a missing manifest element. Sorted!"

## Key Information

- Nothing has changed; PlayerDebugMode remains supported.
- Adobe staff confirmed they "load unsigned panels in 25.x every day."
- PPro 25.0 integrates CEP12, so you'd need to set PlayerDebugMode again (for CEP12 instead of CEP11), in order to load unsigned extensions.

## Correct Setup for CEP 12

On MacOS, type the following into Terminal, then relaunch Finder (either via rebooting, or from the Force Quit dialog): `defaults write /Users/<username>/Library/Preferences/com.adobe.CSXS.12.plist PlayerDebugMode 1`

Extensions should be placed in:
Mac: /Library/Application Support/Adobe/CEP/extensions (Note: That's the root /Library, not a specific user's ~/Library...)

## Important Note About CEP's Future

As of Premiere Pro 25.6, CEP extensions to Premiere Pro have been superseded by UXP Extensibility. If you are starting new development, start in UXP. CEP extensions continue to be supported; the plan is to support both CEP and UXP for a calendar year, after which they will remove support for CEP extensibility.

results:
Based on the search results, here's what I found about the "Cannot Load Unsigned CEP 12 Extensions" issue in Premiere Pro on macOS 15:

## Issue Summary

A user reported being unable to load any unsigned CEP 12 extensions (custom panels or test panels) in Premiere Pro 2025 (version 25.2.3) on macOS Sequoia 15.1, despite correctly setting PlayerDebugMode as described in all Adobe documentation.

## Status: Fixed

The issue was resolved when they "figured out that there was a missing manifest element. Sorted!"

## Key Information

- Nothing has changed; PlayerDebugMode remains supported.
- Adobe staff confirmed they "load unsigned panels in 25.x every day."
- PPro 25.0 integrates CEP12, so you'd need to set PlayerDebugMode again (for CEP12 instead of CEP11), in order to load unsigned extensions.

## Correct Setup for CEP 12

On MacOS, type the following into Terminal, then relaunch Finder (either via rebooting, or from the Force Quit dialog): `defaults write /Users/<username>/Library/Preferences/com.adobe.CSXS.12.plist PlayerDebugMode 1`

Extensions should be placed in:
Mac: /Library/Application Support/Adobe/CEP/extensions (Note: That's the root /Library, not a specific user's ~/Library...)

## Important Note About CEP's Future

As of Premiere Pro 25.6, CEP extensions to Premiere Pro have been superseded by UXP Extensibility. If you are starting new development, start in UXP. CEP extensions continue to be supported; the plan is to support both CEP and UXP for a calendar year, after which they will remove support for CEP extensibility.

2) ...m","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/cep-panel-questions-1-is-chrome-necessary-for-debugging-or-can-edge-a-chromium-work-2-more/m-p/14369096"},{"title":"Getting-Started-guides/Client-side Debugging at master · Adobe-CEP/Getting-Started-guides","url":"https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Getting-Started-guides/tree/master/Client-side%20Debugging"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Adobe CEP debug mode and alternatives:

## Adobe CEP Debug Mode Setup

### Standard Method (PlayerDebugMode)

If you want to bypass the check for extension signatures, you can bypass the check by editing the CSXS preference properties file.

**Windows:**
Open regedit > HKEY_CURRENT_USER/Software/Adobe/CSXS.8, then add a new entry PlayerDebugMode of type "string" with the value of "1".

**Mac:**
In the Terminal, type: `defaults write com.adobe.CSXS.8 PlayerDebugMode 1`. On macOS, Terminal is located in (Applications > Utilities > Terminal).(no content)Note that CSXS.8 is given with the assumption that you are developing the extension for CEP 8. If you are developing extension for a previous version of CEP, replace 8 with the corresponding version number.

### Important Notes

Setting the debug mode to the updated CEP version is the #1 reason that extensions stop working when a new CC version comes out. The current version is CEP 11.(no content)CEP12 exists, but some applications like Premiere Pro haven't yet integrated it.

### Toggling Debug Mode Efficiently

Adobe CEP panel devs constantly need to switch the player debug mode on for building tools, and off for testing them. This usually means editing the registry on Windows or running a terminal command on Mac for each CEP / CEF version which can get pretty cumbersome.(no content)There are scripts available to scan for all installed CEP versions on the system, and then toggle them on or off at once using Node.js.

### Remote Debugging Setup

CEP supports remote debugging for HTML extensions from 5.0. Create a ".debug" file in the extension root directory. The .debug file contains remote debug ports.(no content)The value of Port should be between 1024 and 65535 (not including 65535), otherwise remote debugging and dev tools will not work.

---

The search results don't show specific information about SIP (System Integrity Protection) bypass methods or alternative environment variables specifically for bypassing SIP on macOS. The standard approach uses the `defaults write` command for the PlayerDebugMode preference. If you need more specific information about SIP-related workarounds for CEP development, I can perform an additional search.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on my search results, here's what I found about the macOS 15 Sequoia CEP PlayerDebugMode issue with Adobe:

## Summary of the Issue

Users have reported being unable to load unsigned CEP 12 extensions in Premiere Pro 2025 (version 25.2.3) on macOS Sequoia 15.1, despite correctly setting PlayerDebugMode according to Adobe documentation.

## Key Findings

### The Issue is Marked as Fixed
Adobe figured out that there was a missing manifest element, and the issue has been sorted.(no content)Nothing has changed; PlayerDebugMode remains supported.

### Important Troubleshooting Steps

1. **Restart Finder after enabling PlayerDebugMode**: "Confirming (because it's bitten me before): You've restarted Finder, since enabling PlayerDebugMode, yes?"

2. **Use the correct CEP version**: PPro 25.0 integrates CEP12, so you'd need to set PlayerDebugMode again (for CEP12 instead of CEP11), in order to load unsigned extensions.

3. **Correct command for CEP 12 on Mac**:
   The command should be: `defaults write com.adobe.CSXS.12 PlayerDebugMode 1`

### Related Issues

Some users experienced blank CEP panels in Illustrator 29.5 that worked fine in 29.4, with the extension behaving as if PlayerDebugMode was set to 0.(no content)In some cases, if PlayerDebugMode is set to 1, extension panels show up but remain blank.

### Workarounds to Try

1. On Mac, type the following into Terminal, then relaunch Finder (either via rebooting, or from the Force Quit dialog): `defaults write /Users/<username>/Library/Preferences/com.adobe.CSXS.11.plist PlayerDebugMode 1`

2. Check your extension's manifest file for missing elements

3. Check the logs as they might have some entries for what is causing the trouble. If you are using an unsigned extension and the same was loading on a previous version, the first step would be to check the logs.

The root cause in many cases appears to be either using the wrong CEP version number in the PlayerDebugMode command, not restarting Finder after setting the preference, or missing manifest elements in the extension itself.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"How-to: Replace preference files in Mavericks · Tales of a Running Bird","url":"https://manytricks.com/blog/?p=3049"},{"title":"Mavericks & Preference Caching – macmule","url":"https://macmule.com/2014/02/07/mavericks-preference-caching/"},{"title":"GitHub - studioxop/CEP_PHXS: Sample script HTML configurator like panel","url":"https://github.com/studioxop/CEP_PHXS"},{"title":"Mac’s Hidden Daemons: Should You Be Exorcising 'cfprefsd' and 'cloudd'?","url":"https://eshop.macsales.com/blog/45408-seeing-cfprefsd-and-cloudd-should-you-be-exorcising-macs-hidden-daemons/"},{"title":"Setting Cep Debug Mode and Log Level the Easy Way | Creative-Scripts.com","url":"https://creative-scripts.com/setting-cep-debug-and-log-level/"},{"title":"What Is cfprefsd and Fix It High CPU Issue?","url":"https://www.doyourdata.com/wiki/cfprefsd.html"},{"title":"Debugging Your Adobe Panel","url":"https://blog.developer.adobe.com/en/publish/2019/06/debugging-your-adobe-panel"},{"title":"Unity3d OS X Clean up player prefs / plist | Pete's cookbook","url":"https://pedrevans.wordpress.com/2015/06/23/unity3d-os-x-clean-up-player-prefs-plist/"},{"title":"What is cfprefsd & How to Fix cfprefsd High CPU Usage?","url":"https://iboysoft.com/wiki/cfprefsd.html"},{"title":"AINesting - Download Nesting plugin for Adobe Illustrator","url":"http://mac.e-cut.ru/index.php?view=article&id=125"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about killing cfprefsd to refresh the plist cache for CEP PlayerDebugMode:

## CEP PlayerDebugMode and cfprefsd Cache Refresh

### The Problem
Starting with macOS 10.9, Apple introduced a caching mechanism for plist files. Your modifications to plist files does not take effect until the cache gets updated (on a periodic basis, you cannot know exactly when the update will happen).(no content)In Mavericks, preferences are managed by a background daemon, cfprefsd. This service reads the preferences file once, when you first run the app. It then receives notifications if you change the program's settings while the program is running, and then writes them to the actual preferences file at certain points in time. But cfprefsd always has a copy of those settings in its cache, and that's what the app gets when it checks its settings.

### Setting CEP Debug Mode
On Mac, in the Terminal, type: `defaults write com.adobe.CSXS.8 PlayerDebugMode 1`(no content)You can set this for multiple CEP versions: `defaults write com.adobe.CSXS.9 PlayerDebugMode 1`, `defaults write com.adobe.CSXS.8 PlayerDebugMode 1`, `defaults write com.adobe.CSXS.7 PlayerDebugMode 1` and so on. These entries will enable debug extensions to be displayed in the host applications. If you are developing extension for a previous version of CEP, replace 9 with the corresponding version number.

### Solution: Kill cfprefsd
If you've set the debug mode and are still getting the error about unsigned extensions, try killing the cfprefsd process.(no content)To make sure your modifications take effect, there are two methods: Kill cfprefsd process.(no content)Kill cfprefsd process. It will restart automatically. Then the update takes effect. Alternatively, restart your Mac, or log out the current user and re-log in.

### Recommended Command
Thanks to Kris Coppieters for the `killall -u \`whoami\` cfprefsd` method of killing cfprefsd, this method is easier than other documented ones.

Alternatively, you can use:
Run `killall cfprefsd` in Terminal which will flush all settings to plists and relaunch the cfprefsd agent.

Or this more targeted approach:
`kill $(ps x | awk '/[c]fprefsd/{ print $1 }')` - When next the application starts, the cache should be empty.

### Complete Workflow
1. Quit any Adobe applications
2. Set the debug mode: `defaults write com.adobe.CSXS.X PlayerDebugMode 1` (replace X with your CEP version)
3. Kill cfprefsd: `killall -u $(whoami) cfprefsd`
4. Restart your Adobe application

To turn off the debug mode, do the same just changing the 1 that comes after PlayerDebugMode to 0.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on my search results, here's information about CEP manifest.xml required elements, specifically for HostList, Host, and version specifications in CEP 12:

## CEP manifest.xml Required Elements

### Basic Structure
First is an XML manifest, which must live at: /CSXS/manifest.xml (CSXS being the old name of CEP).(no content)The CSXS/manifest.xml is the extension manifest (XML format) defining the extension's identity, supported host apps/versions, and panel settings. This file is required; without it, After Effects will not recognize your extension.

### Key Required Elements

Key fields in manifest.xml for a CEP panel include:
- **ExtensionBundleId** – A unique reverse-domain identifier for your extension bundle (e.g., com.mycompany.myextension)
- **Extension Id** – A unique ID for the specific extension (panel). Often this is ExtensionBundleId.panel (e.g., com.mycompany.myextension.panel). This ID will appear twice (in ExtensionList and later in the Extension Id node).

### HostList and Host Version

The Host Name & Version defines the list of host application IDs and versions that your extension is built to support.(no content)**HostList** – The Adobe apps that will host this extension. Use the host's code and a version range. For After Effects, the host code is "AEFT". For example: `<Host Name="AEFT" Version="[16.0,99.0]"/>` This indicates the panel is compatible with AE 16.0 and up. Using a range or "*", you can future-proof the manifest so the panel doesn't disappear when the app is updated.

### Host Codes
The HostList codes include: PHXS: Photoshop, PHSP: Photoshop (older code), ILST: Illustrator, FLPR: Flash Pro, PPRO: Premiere Pro, AEFT: After Effects, PRLD: Prelude, IDSN: InDesign, AICY: InCopy, AUDT: Audition.

### Example Manifest Structure (CEP 11+)

A simplified example manifest structure:
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<ExtensionManifest ExtensionBundleId="com.mycompany.myextension" 
                   ExtensionBundleVersion="1.0.0" 
                   Version="11.0">
  <ExtensionList>
    <Extension Id="com.mycompany.myextension.panel" Version="1.0.0" />
  </ExtensionList>
  <ExecutionEnvironment>
    <HostList>
      <Host Name="AEFT" Version="[16.0,99.0]"/>
    </HostList>
    <LocaleList>
      <Locale Code="All"/>
    </LocaleList>
    <RequiredRuntimeList>
      <RequiredRuntime Name="CSXS" Version="11.0"/>
    </RequiredRuntimeList>
  </ExecutionEnvironment>
  ...
</ExtensionManifest>
```(no content)"The CEP 12 HTML Extension Cookbook is a great resource provided by Adobe" for more detailed information on CEP 12 specific configurations.

You can adjust the product version targeted by modifying the range inside the HostList element of the CSXS/manifest.xml file.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

results:
Based on my search results, here's information about CEP manifest.xml required elements, specifically for HostList, Host, and version specifications in CEP 12:

## CEP manifest.xml Required Elements

### Basic Structure
First is an XML manifest, which must live at: /CSXS/manifest.xml (CSXS being the old name of CEP).(no content)The CSXS/manifest.xml is the extension manifest (XML format) defining the extension's identity, supported host apps/versions, and panel settings. This file is required; without it, After Effects will not recognize your extension.

### Key Required Elements

Key fields in manifest.xml for a CEP panel include:
- **ExtensionBundleId** – A unique reverse-domain identifier for your extension bundle (e.g., com.mycompany.myextension)
- **Extension Id** – A unique ID for the specific extension (panel). Often this is ExtensionBundleId.panel (e.g., com.mycompany.myextension.panel). This ID will appear twice (in ExtensionList and later in the Extension Id node).

### HostList and Host Version

The Host Name & Version defines the list of host application IDs and versions that your extension is built to support.(no content)**HostList** – The Adobe apps that will host this extension. Use the host's code and a version range. For After Effects, the host code is "AEFT". For example: `<Host Name="AEFT" Version="[16.0,99.0]"/>` This indicates the panel is compatible with AE 16.0 and up. Using a range or "*", you can future-proof the manifest so the panel doesn't disappear when the app is updated.

### Host Codes
The HostList codes include: PHXS: Photoshop, PHSP: Photoshop (older code), ILST: Illustrator, FLPR: Flash Pro, PPRO: Premiere Pro, AEFT: After Effects, PRLD: Prelude, IDSN: InDesign, AICY: InCopy, AUDT: Audition.

### Example Manifest Structure (CEP 11+)

A simplified example manifest structure:
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<ExtensionManifest ExtensionBundleId="com.mycompany.myextension" 
                   ExtensionBundleVersion="1.0.0" 
                   Version="11.0">
  <ExtensionList>
    <Extension Id="com.mycompany.myextension.panel" Version="1.0.0" />
  </ExtensionList>
  <ExecutionEnvironment>
    <HostList>
      <Host Name="AEFT" Version="[16.0,99.0]"/>
    </HostList>
    <LocaleList>
      <Locale Code="All"/>
    </LocaleList>
    <RequiredRuntimeList>
      <RequiredRuntime Name="CSXS" Version="11.0"/>
    </RequiredRuntimeList>
  </ExecutionEnvironment>
  ...
</ExtensionManifest>
```(no content)"The CEP 12 HTML Extension Cookbook is a great resource provided by Adobe" for more detailed information on CEP 12 specific configurations.

You can adjust the product version targeted by modifying the range inside the HostList element of the CSXS/manifest.xml file.

content.text:
Based on my research, here is a comprehensive guide to solving CEP EvalScript errors when debug mode doesn't work:

---

# CEP EvalScript Error Solutions When Debug Mode Fails

## Problem Overview

The "EvalScript error" typically occurs when:
1. PlayerDebugMode is not correctly configured for your CEP version
2. macOS preference caching prevents changes from taking effect
3. Manifest.xml is missing required elements
4. JSX file syntax errors cause silent failures

---

## Solution 1: Set PlayerDebugMode for the Correct CEP Version

**This is the #1 cause of CEP issues when Adobe apps update.** Adobe Premiere Pro 2025 (v25.x) uses **CEP 12**, not CEP 11.

### macOS Commands:

```bash
# For Premiere Pro 2025 (CEP 12)
defaults write com.adobe.CSXS.12 PlayerDebugMode 1

# For older versions (CEP 11)
defaults write com.adobe.CSXS.11 PlayerDebugMode 1

# Or using full path
defaults write /Users/$(whoami)/Library/Preferences/com.adobe.CSXS.12.plist PlayerDebugMode 1
```

### Windows Registry:

Add a String key named `PlayerDebugMode` with value `1` to:
- CEP 12: `HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Adobe\CSXS.12`
- CEP 11: `HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Adobe\CSXS.11`

---

## Solution 2: Force macOS Preference Cache Refresh

Starting with macOS 10.9, Apple caches plist files. Your modifications may not take effect until the cache updates.

### Method 1: Kill cfprefsd (Recommended)
```bash
# Kill the preferences daemon (it auto-restarts)
killall -u $(whoami) cfprefsd
```

### Method 2: Restart Finder
```bash
killall Finder
```

### Method 3: Log Out/Reboot
Log out and back in, or restart your Mac.

### Complete Workflow:
```bash
# 1. Quit all Adobe applications
# 2. Set debug mode for CEP 12
defaults write com.adobe.CSXS.12 PlayerDebugMode 1

# 3. Kill preference cache
killall -u $(whoami) cfprefsd

# 4. Restart Finder
killall Finder

# 5. Relaunch Premiere Pro
```

---

## Solution 3: Verify Manifest.xml Elements

The [Adobe Community thread](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-bugs/cannot-load-unsigned-cep-12-extensions-in-premiere-pro-25-on-macos-15-playerdebugmode-ignored/idc-p/15333640) confirms that a "missing manifest element" was the root cause for the macOS 15 issue.

### Required Manifest Elements:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<ExtensionManifest ExtensionBundleId="com.yourcompany.extension" 
                   ExtensionBundleVersion="1.0.0" 
                   Version="12.0">
  <ExtensionList>
    <Extension Id="com.yourcompany.extension.panel" Version="1.0.0" />
  </ExtensionList>
  <ExecutionEnvironment>
    <HostList>
      <Host Name="PPRO" Version="[25.0,99.0]"/>
    </HostList>
    <LocaleList>
      <Locale Code="All"/>
    </LocaleList>
    <RequiredRuntimeList>
      <RequiredRuntime Name="CSXS" Version="12.0"/>
    </RequiredRuntimeList>
  </ExecutionEnvironment>
  <!-- DispatchInfoList, LifeCycle, UI, etc. -->
</ExtensionManifest>
```

### Key Elements to Check:
- **RequiredRuntime Version** must match your CEP version (12.0 for PPro 2025)
- **Host Version** range must include your Premiere Pro version
- **Extension Id** must be consistent throughout the manifest

---

## Solution 4: Fix JSX Syntax Errors

EvalScript fails silently on JSX errors. Common issues:

### 1. File Encoding
Save JSX files as **UTF-8** (not ASCII):
```bash
# Check file encoding
file -I your-script.jsx
```

### 2. Timing Issues
Don't call evalScript immediately on page load:
```javascript
// BAD - runs before panel is ready
csInterface.evalScript('myFunction()');

// GOOD - wait for DOM and panel ready
document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function() {
    setTimeout(function() {
        csInterface.evalScript('myFunction()');
    }, 100);
});
```

### 3. Debug JSX Separately
Test your JSX in ExtendScript Toolkit before using in CEP:
```javascript
// Wrap in try-catch for better error messages
try {
    // Your JSX code here
} catch(e) {
    $.writeln("Error: " + e.message + " at line " + e.line);
    "Error: " + e.message;
}
```

---

## Solution 5: Extension Installation Location

Ensure your extension is in the correct location:

### macOS:
```
/Library/Application Support/Adobe/CEP/extensions/
```
(Note: This is the root `/Library`, NOT `~/Library`)

### Windows:
```
C:\Program Files (x86)\Common Files\Adobe\CEP\extensions\
```

---

## Solution 6: Cross-Platform ZXP Signing Issue (2024)

Per [Adobe's bug report](https://community.adobe.com/t5/exchange-bugs/cross-platform-zxp-signing-compatibility-known-issue-and-workaround-2024/idi-p/14961412), ZXP files signed on one platform may fail on another.

### Workaround:
```bash
# Remove macOS metadata from extension folder before signing
find /path/to/extension -name ".DS_Store" -delete
find /path/to/extension -name "__MACOSX" -type d -exec rm -rf {} +

# Remove symlinks (especially in node_modules)
find /path/to/extension -type l -delete
```

---

## Quick Diagnostic Script for macOS

```bash
#!/bin/bash
echo "=== CEP Debug Mode Status ==="
echo "CEP 12: $(defaults read com.adobe.CSXS.12 PlayerDebugMode 2>/dev/null || echo 'Not set')"
echo "CEP 11: $(defaults read com.adobe.CSXS.11 PlayerDebugMode 2>/dev/null || echo 'Not set')"
echo "CEP 10: $(defaults read com.adobe.CSXS.10 PlayerDebugMode 2>/dev/null || echo 'Not set')"

echo ""
echo "=== Extension Locations ==="
ls -la /Library/Application\ Support/Adobe/CEP/extensions/ 2>/dev/null || echo "No system-wide extensions"
ls -la ~/Library/Application\ Support/Adobe/CEP/extensions/ 2>/dev/null || echo "No user extensions"
```

---

## Important Note: CEP End of Life

Per [Adobe's announcement](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/cep-panels-not-visible/m-p/14952782), as of Premiere Pro 25.6, CEP has been superseded by UXP. Adobe plans to support both for one calendar year before removing CEP support. Consider migrating to UXP for new development.

---

## Sources

- [CEP EvalScript Error Discussion](https://community.adobe.com/t5/after-effects/cep-hello-world-returns-quot-evalscript-error-quot/m-p/9366081)
- [CEP 12 Unsigned Extensions Bug Report (Fixed)](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-bugs/cannot-load-unsigned-cep-12-extensions-in-premiere-pro-25-on-macos-15-playerdebugmode-ignored/idc-p/15333640)
- [CEP Panel Developer Update for 25.0](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-beta-discussions/cep-panel-developers-update-necessary-to-load-unsigned-panels-in-25-0-beta/td-p/14782378)
- [Client-side Debugging Guide](https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Getting-Started-guides/blob/master/Client-side%20Debugging/readme.md)
- [Setting CEP Debug Mode the Easy Way](https://creative-scripts.com/setting-cep-debug-and-log-level/)
- [CEP 11 HTML Extension Cookbook](https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/CEP-Resources/blob/master/CEP_11.x/Documentation/CEP%2011.1%20HTML%20Extension%20Cookbook.md)
- [Cross-Platform ZXP Signing Issue 2024](https://community.adobe.com/t5/exchange-bugs/cross-platform-zxp-signing-compatibility-known-issue-and-workaround-2024/idi-p/14961412)
